DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Military Strike `Decapitates' Noriega From Dictatorship
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday he ordered the military strike in Panama to seize Manuel Antonio Noriega and end ``reckless threats and attacks'' against Americans. Noriega eluded capture and the administration put a $1 million bounty on his head. Even though Noriega dropped out of sight, the United States said, ``As a practical matter, we have decapitated him from the dictatorship.'' The White House announced a $1 million reward for information leading to his capture. In addition, Panamanians were offered $150 for each firearm they surrendered. Pentagon officials declared the operation in Panama a military success, saying Noriega's forces mostly had fled or were fleeing though some fighting continued. Reaction from Congress, both Democratic and Republican, was mostly favorable. Bush, hoping to break a nearly two-year stalemate with Noriega, dispatched 9,500 soldiers and Marines to back up the 13,000 U.S. troops already in Panama for a 1 a.m. assault against army bases and the general's headquarters. In a televised address from the Oval Office, a somber Bush told the nation, ``I took this action only after reaching the conclusion that every other avenue was closed and the lives of American citizens were in grave danger.'' In the fighting _ codenamed ``Operation Just Cause'' by the Pentagon _ 15 U.S. military personnel were killed, many more were wounded and one was missing. In addition, a woman dependent was killed, the Pentagon said. Four helicopters crashed, believed to have been brought down by gunfire. Noting the loss of American lives, Bush said, ``No president takes such action lightly.'' Lt. Gen. Tom Kelly, Army deputy chief of staff, said, ``One dead American is too many, but thank God the numbers don't appear too high right now.'' He said, ``It looks like the organized resistance is a thing of the past.'' Bush, up much of the night, monitored the fighting in Panama. He took a break Wednesday evening to attend a White House Christmas party. Some Americans were reported taken hostage in the Marriott Hotel in Panama City. Late in the day, U.S. Marines arrived at the site and escorted many Americans out of the building. Kelly called Noriega ``a crafty devil'' and said he had not been spotted Wednesday. He said U.S. forces had observed Noriega several times on Tuesday. ``We thought we had a pretty good idea of where he was last night. We went there and he wasn't there.'' ``He has gone to ground,'' Kelly said. Even so, he expressed confidence Noriega would be located, saying ``we have every spigot turned on'' to find him. He said there was no indication Noriega had left Panama. The general said ``much of the PDF (Panamanian Defense Forces) is fleeing in the face of the U.S. military units.'' He added, ``We have a concern that they have gone off into the jungle. There is every chance that we will go off after them.'' Kelly said he expected the canal to reopen Thursday. Bush said the United States would withdraw its force as soon as possible. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said he could not speculate how long U.S. troops would remain in action. Bush was roundly criticized when he kept U.S. forces on the sidelines during an unsuccessful coup attempt against Noriega on Oct. 3. In contrast, congressional leaders generally supported the president's decision to use force. ``When there is the engagement of U.S. forces in the field, it behooves all of us to give that support,'' House Speaker Thomas Foley said. ``It was made necessary by the reckless actions of Gen. Noriega,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. But Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., called Bush's action ``a trigger-happy act of gunboat diplomacy'' which violates the Constitution. And, Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said Bush should not have acted without the support and aid of other Central American nations. William J. Bennett, the director of national drug control policy, said of Noriega, ``I think we can safely conclude that this ends his career as a drug trafficker. He's not running drugs. He's not running Panama. He's just running. And that's good.''
